Notes: The foundational paper arguing that cognitive processes can extend into the environment.
Explains perception and action as two sides of the same process of minimizing prediction error.
Classic study using a flicker paradigm to demonstrate the need for attention to perceive change.
The findings are used to argue that attention is necessary for forming a conscious percept.
Argues for the research program of finding the minimal neural mechanisms sufficient for consciousness.
Defines A-consciousness as the state accessible to reasoning and report.
Defines P-consciousness as raw subjective experience, independent of report.
Argues that phenomenal consciousness (via recurrent processing) can exist without the global broadcast required by GNW.
Posits that phenomenal feel arises from local recurrent processing, which can occur pre-attentively.
Proposes that understanding others' actions is based on activating one's own motor system (embodied simulation).
The 'Chinese Room' argument critiques the idea that syntax (computation) is sufficient for semantics (understanding).
Argues that seeing is a way of acting and the world can be used as an 'outside memory'.
Proposes a specific architecture (the Conscious Turing Machine) as a model for artificial consciousness.
Advocates for using phenomenological methods to map the structure of experience to be matched with physical structures.
The 'Mary's Room' thought experiment is used as evidence against physicalism.
Demonstrates choice blindness in a real-world decision task.
Defines affordances as opportunities for action directly perceived by an agent.
Models cognitive access as a form of active inference where the system selects what information to process.
Argues that the search for NCCs should be replaced by a search for shared structure between experience and physical systems.
The 'gorillas in our midst' study, a famous demonstration of inattentional blindness.
Provides a formal framework for IIT using the categorical language of process theories.
Uses category theory to formalize the relationship between phenomenal states and perceptual reports.
Argues that category theory is a suitable language for formalizing theories in consciousness science.
Discusses the nature of time and consciousness from a process-holism perspective.
Develops a categorical model of consciousness drawing on formalisms from quantum theory.
Builds a formal model of a conscious universe using topos theory.
The model provides a framework for understanding and approaching the complexities of artificial consciousness.
The model helps define awareness in terms of testable attributes.
The model posits intentional action as a minimal necessary condition for aware processing.
The paper uses formal modeling to develop the multidimensional model.
The paper uses conceptual analysis to develop the multidimensional model.
Avian consciousness is a specific instance of consciousness.
Used to probe the neural correlates of avian consciousness.
Neuroimaging is used to measure neural activity in the brain.
Neuroimaging is used in conjunction with the delayed detection task.
Neural activity in the NCL correlates with the crows' perceptual reports.
The two-stage process explains how subjective experience arises from neural activity.
The two-stage process explains the neural activity related to avian consciousness.
The global neuronal workspace theory is suggested as a possible explanation for the findings.
Heart rate variability entropy (HRV) can discriminate disorders of consciousness
Resting-state fMRI brain connectivity of the central autonomic network is correlated with heart rate variability entropy.
Resting-state fMRI brain connectivity of the central autonomic network is correlated with heart rate variability entropy.
The centrencephalic system is crucial in the organization of conscious and volitional functions.
The centrencephalic system is crucial in the organization of conscious and volitional functions.
The centrencephalic system relies on attention.
The centrencephalic system relies on awareness.
The selection triangle relies on motivation.
The selection triangle relies on action selection.
The selection triangle relies on target selection.
Evidence from anencephaly suggests that brainstem mechanisms are integral to the constitution of the conscious state.
Evidence from hydranencephaly suggests that brainstem mechanisms are integral to the constitution of the conscious state.
Evidence from absence seizures suggests that brainstem mechanisms are integral to the constitution of the conscious state.
The Sprague effect demonstrates that visual attention and perception are mediated at both forebrain and midbrain levels.
Oscillatory coherence explains how information gains access to awareness.
The theory relies on the concept of neuronal oscillations.
The theory relies on the concept of neuronal coherence.
Coherent oscillations facilitate perception-action coupling.
The global workspace relies on neuronal oscillations.
Coherent oscillations facilitate visual processing.
Coherent oscillations facilitate attention.
JDT posits content-specific NCCs.
JDT posits consciousness is fundamentally pluralistic.
Integrative Pluralism suggests theories provide complementary and compatible explanations.
MCI maps the concepts and measures of theories.
QBE uses Bayesian updating.
CRIT evaluates theories against a set of criteria.
ARC uses falsification combined with adversarial collaboration.
Hot topics are specific cases that dominate debates in the field.
Cold cases are instances of empirical evidence that have received little attention.
The replication crisis is related to the number of cold cases.
APD explains A-consciousness.
APD explains P-consciousness.
MGH posits multiple generators of consciousness.
The AIM is related to the cyclical alternating pattern.
The AIM mediates cognitive changes between sleep and wakefulness.
The thalamo-cortical integrating mechanism may underlie awareness.
Total consciousness requires awareness.
Total consciousness requires memory.
Total consciousness requires emotion.
Total consciousness requires self-awareness.
Mentions the global workspace theory in relation to attention.
The method aims to ensure meaningful comparisons between theories.
Formulating multiple hypotheses is a method for theory comparison.
Strong Inference is a method for theory comparison.
IIT and GNW are different theories of consciousness that can be compared.
Strong inference uses experimental design to test hypotheses.
Recurrent Processing Theory explains visual processing.
Global Neuronal Workspace Theory explains access consciousness.
Integrated Information Theory explains phenomenal consciousness.
Essential positions can help define a categorical framework for consciousness theories.
